item.title: Civilization 7: What Are Migrants?
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How to Use Migrants in Civilization 7
  • How to Get Migrants in Civilization 7

In Civ 7 , there are various Units and each one play a different role in the game. It is important for players to understand how each Unit works in Civilization 7 so they can take full advantage of it and optimize their strategy. While Civilian Units may not seem as crucial as Military Units, gamers shouldn't underestimate their value.

The Migrant is one of the various Civilian Units in Civilization 7 and can be a particularly huge help at the start of the game, when settlement yields are still relatively low. This guide helps gamers understand why Migrants will spawn and how to use them.

How to Use Migrants in Civilization 7

What Is a Migrant in Civ 7?

While playing a game of Civilization 7 , Migrants will sometimes appear in players' settlements. Before moving on to the next turn, the game will prompt players to move the Migrant. However, if they're not familiar with these Units, they won't know exactly what they should do to take advantage of it.

  • Migrants are Civilian Units in Civ 7 so they have no military value. To use a Migrant, gamers must move it to a tile that is not being worked and claim it as a Rural District. In short, they're a free citizen for the player's settlement .

When a Migrant appears in a settlement, gamers can activate it by selecting it and choosing the "Resettlement" option on the bottom right corner of the screen. This will add +1 Population to the settlement, making it possible to work an additional tile.

How to Get Migrants in Civilization 7

What Makes Migrants Spawn in Civ 7?

Migrants are more of a bonus in Civ 7 , rather than a goal that players can work towards. During a game of Civilization 7 , there are certain Narrative Events that the player must complete as the Leader of their civilization. Their response may result in a Migrant Unit appearing in a settlement. Take the following example:

In this case, there was a flood in this settlement, and the player must decide how to act. If they house the civilians in the barracks, a Military Unit will spawn, but if they place them in the central quarter, a Migrant will spawn instead. If players activate tooltips and hover over each response, they can see the outcome of each choice.

The best way to consistently produce Migrants in Civilization 7 is to play as Harriet Tubman until gamers reach Leader Level 2 and unlock the Lantern Memento . When selected, the Lantern Memento causes a Migrant to spawn in the Capital whenever an Espionage diplomatic action is completed without detection .

item.title: God of War's Atreus is a Great Character, But the Series Shouldn't Get Carried Away
item.description:
As the wait for the next God of War game stretches on, many have speculated that Atreus will replace Kratos as the series' lead. This assumption stems from the ending of God of War Ragnarok , which sees Atreus setting off on his own adventure to find the rest of the Giants while Kratos hangs back in the Norse realms, ostensibly taking Tyr's place as the God of War.

There are a number of benefits to such a radical creative choice, not the least of which being the potential for new, exciting narrative threads. Unlike Kratos, Atreus is at the very start of his life: he has suffered trauma and had his share of adventure already, certainly, but he still has much to learn. Falling in love, living on his own, and making hard decisions without the guidance and assistance of his father are just some of the experiences waiting for the young god, and this means more room to grow when compared to Kratos. Of course, there's also the gameplay side of the equation, as the next God of War could offer a radical mechanical departure with Atreus at the helm. Despite these promising factors, though, making Atreus the new face of the series is still risky.

Atreus Might Not Be Cut Out for the Role of God of War's Protagonist

Atreus Helming the Series Means Leaving Kratos Out of Key Moments

Another common assumption among God of War fans is that Kratos and Atreus will travel to other pantheons in upcoming entries. There's obviously a precedent for this, as Kratos' Norse realm transplant worked out surprisingly well, and with the games gesturing toward other mythologies, like those of Ancient Egypt and Ireland, the move to these new lands seems more plausible than ever.

But a big reason why the pivot to "Norway" worked so well in God of War 2018 is because Kratos remained a constant. His personality may have softened slightly since his last canon appearance, but the heart of his characterization was still intact: his inclusion is why the series is still " God of War " in spite of its myriad changes. If Kratos were to effectively sit out future trips to distinct, unique mythological pantheons, the franchise would be at risk of losing its identity. It would be akin to an anthology series or a spin-off rather than the fiery and epic tale that audiences have become familiar with.

It may seem relatively trivial, but the very title of the franchise is a direct reference to Kratos, a symbol of his importance within the series' DNA.

God of War Could Have Its Cake and Eat It Too

It seems reasonable to think that Atreus will be playable in subsequent God of War games, and the natural evolution from Ragnarok may be to make him the star of the show, as it were. But this doesn't mean that he needs to completely usurp his father as the series' lead: Atreus could be at the center of a spin-off series, possibly one that features less predictable departures from the God of War formula.

Such a strategy could allow God of War to explore new pantheons and narrative concepts without making irreversible changes, like killing or retiring Kratos. These Atreus-centric games could be like the Persona to God of War 's Shin Megami Tensei , or the Dirge of Cerberus to God of War 's Final Fantasy 7 . In this way, God of War could hold on to its identity as Kratos' franchise while still moving forward with fresh ideas and stories based around Atreus.

item.title: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 - All Trosky Towns, Ranked
item.description:
The journey in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 begins in the vast Trosky region, a territory of Bohemia filled with villages, castles, and forests. As the first area explored, this location provides countless opportunities for players to delve into Henry’s path, completing varied quests and uncovering hidden secrets. Moreover, the detailed setting and the developers’ meticulous care make every place captivating.

These towns scattered across Trosky play a key role in the story’s progression and Henry’s survival . This is where the loot collected can be traded with specialized merchants, guaranteeing new equipment and supplies. In addition, the main missions, both from the campaign and from side content, are found in these hubs, promoting exploration and interactions with influential characters in the region.

5 Nebakov

An Interesting Quest, But Limited Content

  • Related Quests: The Finger of God and Back In The Saddle

Despite being the backdrop for one of the best quests in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 , the Nebakov area faces a few drawbacks that prevent it from shining as brightly as other Trosky towns. One issue is the delay in reaching it, since the region becomes accessible only after starting the Back In The Saddle quest. Depending on each player’s pace, getting there can take many hours.

For this reason, there is little incentive to skip portions of the main story and ignore side content solely to arrive quickly, even though a few horses from the local stables can be worthwhile. Nebakov does feature some useful merchants, such as the Fisherman, but beyond those minor details, it lacks anything especially memorable. Possibly, the strong quest connected to Nebakov exists to compensate for the limited range of other content.

4 Zhelejov

A Place For Henry To Sleep And Stay Clean In Kingdom Come: Deliverance

  • Related Quests: Wine, Women and Blood; Frogs

Compared to the other Trosky towns in Kingdom Come: Deliverance , Zhelejov might appear less captivating, since it offers fewer shops than alternate locations and also lacks a variety of remarkable quests. Even with these shortcomings, however, it still provides some reasons for Henry to stop by from time to time, especially for players looking to take part in melee encounters.

Interacting with Innkeeper Lawrece in the northern part of Zhelejov can initiate the Wine, Women and Blood quest, which draws Henry into fistfights against multiple opponents. Besides that, Zhelejov has a respectable spot for establishing a base, plus a bathhouse that delivers better personal hygiene for Henry and the clothing he wears, outdoing the bathtubs scattered around the map.

3 Tachov

Blacksmith Radovan Makes It One Of The Best Towns In Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2

  • Related Quests: The Blacksmith’s Son, The Jaunt, Mice

Though it may not offer the same excitement as Troskowitz, Tachov in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 does include features its neighbor lacks, such as Blacksmith Radovan. This skilled merchant stands among the finest in the Trosky region, selling many of the top-tier weapons and armor encountered during the game’s early hours. He is also responsible for teaching the forging mechanics and for making the Basilard available.

Beyond the missions provided by Blacksmith Radovan, which lead players to several corners of the map, Tachov also presents a quest titled Frogs and Mice, enabling Henry to play pranks on residents of other areas and, in certain ways, help settle conflicts among different characters. Aside from that, there are also a handful of side objectives worth tackling, though the town is limited by the smaller number of other vendors in Tachov.

2 Semine

One Of The Best Towns In Trosky In Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2

  • Related Quests: The Jaunt, Materia Prima, Forbidden Fruit

Next to Troskowitz, Semine is arguably one of the Trosky towns in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 with the largest variety of available activities. It is a place that draws repeat visits from many players over the course of the journey. That is because Henry can obtain a first horse there, either by purchasing one or by trying to persuade Groom Ballatay to hand over Pebbles at no cost. Additionally, Semine serves as a setting for various side quests.

Apart from missions, the town contains some memorable individuals, such as Captain Gnarly and Miller Kreyzl, an NPC located in Lower Semine Mill. This character can assign different objectives during the early game, provided players choose to speak with him instead of Blacksmith Radovan during the Wedding Crashers quest. Because of these elements, Semine stands out as a rewarding locale for those aiming to make progress in multiple ways.

1 Troskowitz

The First Town Is The Best In Trosky

  • Related Quests: Wedding Crashers, Laboratores, Invaders

Henry’s adventure truly begins once free exploration of Troskowitz and the rest of the map is possible. Although it is the introductory settlement in Kingdom Come: Deliverance , it remains one of the finest towns in the Trosky region, functioning as a nucleus for numerous quests, from main missions to side tasks. Before departing for another corner of the map, it can be beneficial to explore Troskowitz thoroughly in search of initial items - many of them freely available - such as the Skalitz Axe .

Furthermore, Troskowitz places travelers in a convenient central location on the map, making it likely they will pass through this village while moving between different points of interest if fast travel is not utilized. This positioning is advantageous, given that Troskowitz features a broad range of merchants, including an apothecary, a tailor, a butcher, and even a scribe. It also stands out as the prime location for unloading loot in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 .

item.title: Avowed: Should you Free Prisoner Ilora? (Fort Cell)
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Where to Find Ilora in Avowed
  • Should You Free Ilora in Avowed?
  • How to Free Ilora in Avowed

Avowed is an absolutely massive experience, with a wide range of interesting choices the player will encounter throughout. Very early in the game, players will encounter Ilora , a prisoner held captive in a cell at the starting fort . Whether to free Ilora or not is Avowed 's first narrative choice of consequence, and it has two very different outcomes. In this guide, we'll answer whether you should free Ilora , and explain how to free Ilora if that is what you decide.

Where to Find Ilora in Avowed

Ilora is found about two-thirds of the way through Avowed' s first mission . You'll encounter a large bramble that must be burnt away to pass, and you'll encounter her cell as soon as you pass through the door to the left of the brambles.

For someone stuck in a cell, Ilora does not exactly offer the warmest welcome, as she immediately recoils at the sight of the Godlike's facial features.

Ilora's tone – and the fact that she immediately disparages the Godlike for being part of the Adeyran Empire – makes Garryck highly suspicious from the start. He very quickly suggests that Ilora is not telling the truth , and that freeing her is a bad idea .

With this information, you have to decide whether you should free Ilora. She says she has a boat, but Garryck says that smugglers from Paradis are known liars. So, what is the best option?

Should You Free Ilora in Avowed?

Before we get to whether you should free Ilora from the fort jail in Avowed, it is important to state that you should always remember to save as often as possible. Avowed features multiple save slots, so you can save-scum yourself out of a bad decision. Now, we can look at the outcomes of deciding to free – or not to free – Ilora.

Decide to Free Ilora:

If you free Ilora, Garryck will clearly be displeased. At the time of writing, we are not sure of the long-term effects of individual characters disagreeing with the Godlike, but we do know how this situation turns out.

With Ilora free, she will accompany you throughout the remainder of the mission, all the way to her ship. Once you reach Steadman Ralke – the final boss of the first mission – Ilora will use her pistol to help. Having a third member of your party for some of the tougher combat encounters is the main short-term benefit of freeing Ilora.

After the boss fight, Ilora will lead you to her ship. There is a very nice conversation between the Godlike, Ilora, and Garryck, where Garryck admits that he may have been wrong not to trust her. She will sail with you to Paradis, where it seems her part in the story comes to an end.

Decide Not to Free Ilora:

Should you decide not to free Ilora in Avowed, you may think you'll be leaving her to die in her cell. However, this is not the case. When you leave, Ilora will try one last time to convince you to help. If you still decide to leave her, you will continue through the remainder of the mission with Garryck only.

When you reach Steadman Ralke , Ilora will suddenly appear during your conversation. If your Dexterity is at 2 or above, you'll figure out that she was able to pick the locks. It appears at first that you may be able to make amends with certain dialog choices. Unfortunately, this turns out to be wishful thinking. Ilora decides to use her pistol to help Steadman Ralke .

After defeating Ilora and Steadman Ralke, you can loot the Common Pistol off Ilora's body. This seems to be the only real benefit to not releasing Ilora in Avowed . Ilora's ship is still available at the end of the path, and is still ready to sail the Godlike and Garryck to Paradis.

At the time of writing, we are still working through Avowed 's main story. Any possible long-term effects of freeing or not freeing Ilora are not clear yet. Should there be further consequences, we will update this guide accordingly.

How to Free Ilora in Avowed

If you decide to free Ilora , you can choose either of the following dialog options at the end of the conversation:

  • "Don't worry. I believe you, and I want to help."
  • "Let's go find that key, Garryck."

Ilora will share that the key is in the Warden's Room . To reach this area, turn left at the barred door, and you'll see a stack of climbable crates. Remember that the quest marker is not leading you to the key, it's still set to the barrier. At the top of the crates, you'll see a gap that you must jump. After clearing the gap, clear out all the breakable crates to find a lootable backpack and some Copper Skeyt in a bucket.

From the backpack, jump up to the same ledge that the quest marker is leading you to, but instead of turning left, make a right. You'll find an Essence Potion on a dead body, and right next to that, a breakable floor section. Break through the floor and drop into the Warden's Room. On the desk in front of you will be the Interrogation Log.

Reading the log seems to imply that, while Ilora may not be telling you the truth, her reasons may not be as nefarious as Garryck originally thought. It appears that Ilora may be connected to the Paradisan resistance fighting against the Adeyran Empire, which explains most of her behavior. Make sure to loot the large chest in the corner of the room, then collect the key from the wall near the exit .

Before you free Ilora, unlock the cell to the left of hers and crouch under the broken wall to enter the next cell. You'll find Deerskin Gloves on a dead body.

Now that you have the key, you can unlock Ilora's cell. In the end, it seems like freeing her is the best decision, or at least the 'morally correct' choice. You will gain access to the common pistol not too far into Avowed, so the benefits of not freeing her just do not seem worth it.

item.title: Black Ops 6: How To Unlock The Slipstream Perk (Is It Worth It?)
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How To Unlock The Slipstream Perk
  • How Good Is The Slipstream Perk?

Black Ops 6 is one of the fastest-paced Call of Duty titles to date, thanks to the game's Omnimovement system and the return of Tactical Sprint. First introduced in Modern Warfare 2019 , Tactical Sprint provides players with faster movement speeds, but has faced criticism due to its increased sprint-out time. However, the arrival of a new Perk may have some fans excited due to its unique effect.

The Shadow Hunt Event has debuted in Black Ops 6 , bringing a variety of free rewards for players to unlock. While the TR2 Marksman Rifle is a great addition, it's the Slipstream Perk that could shake up the Black Ops 6 Multiplayer meta. Here’s how to unlock the Slipstream Perk and whether it’s worth using.

How To Unlock The Slipstream Perk

The Slipstream Perk is one of the many rewards available in the Shadow Hunt Event for Black Ops 6 and Warzone . To unlock all rewards for Shadow Hunt, players must complete challenges in either Black Ops 6 Multiplayer, Zombies, or Warzone . Each reward has three associated challenges, one for each mode, but players only need to complete one to claim their reward.

Here is a breakdown of the challenges available to complete in order to unlock the Slipstream Perk:

  • Multiplayer: Get five kills using melee weapons
  • Zombies: Get 200 kills using melee weapons
  • Warzone: Get one melee elimination

Upon unlocking the Slipstream Perk, players can equip it in their Perk 3 slot (or Perk Greed slot) for their Multiplayer loadouts. Players will also receive a 30-Minute Double Weapon XP Token along with the Slipstream Perk, allowing them to level up their weapons quickly.

The Shadow Hunt Event ends on February 20 at 10 AM PT. Once it ends, the Slipstream Perk will move over to the Armory for those who have not already unlocked it.

How Good Is The Slipstream Perk?

The Slipstream Perk offers the benefit of increasing the player's base movement speed at the cost of removing the player's ability to Tactical Sprint. The player's base sprint speed is boosted by approximately 11% with Slipstream. However, this is notably much slower than the speed that players move whilst Tactical Sprinting.

One of the main advantages of Slipstream—aside from the increased movement speed—is its improved sprint-out time. Since players are limited to regular sprinting instead of Tactical Sprinting, they will notice that their weapon is ready much sooner when coming out of a sprint, as Tactical Sprinting typically causes a notable sprint-out time delay.

For players who want to prioritize faster sprint-out times and a slight movement speed boost, Slipstream is a great choice. However, if players want to maximize their mobility, then Double Time may be the better option for the Perk 3 slot, as it extends Tactical Sprint duration rather than removing it.
